description: A five-slide presentation with key information about the Tiger.
title: All About the Tiger

slides.title: Introduction to the Tiger
slides.content: The tiger (Panthera tigris) is the largest cat species and a member of the genus Panthera. It is most recognizable for its dark vertical stripes on orange fur with a white underside. Tigers are solitary, territorial predators native to Asia.

slides.title: Physical Characteristics
content: Tigers can weigh up to 660 pounds and measure up to 11 feet in length, making them the largest big cats.
Each tiger has a unique stripe pattern, similar to human fingerprints, which helps researchers identify individuals.

slides.title: Hunting and Behavior
content: Tigers are ambush predators that rely on stealth and power to hunt deer, wild boar, and other large prey.
They are mostly nocturnal hunters and can eat up to 40 pounds of meat in a single sitting, then go without food for days.

slides.title: Habitat and Distribution
content: Tigers historically ranged from eastern Turkey to the Sea of Japan and south to Sumatra, but now occupy only about 7% of their former range.
They prefer diverse habitats including tropical forests, grasslands, and mangrove swamps across 13 countries in Asia.

slides.title: Conservation Status
content: Tigers are endangered, with some subspecies like the South China tiger possibly extinct in the wild.
Major threats include poaching, habitat loss, and depletion of prey species. Conservation efforts focus on anti-poaching and habitat protection.
